unnormalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey with Ayurveda in Kerala
normalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey with Ayurveda in Kerala

unnormalised: The relentless Mumbai heat was getting to me. My skin was perpetually oily, my digestion felt off, and I was constantly irritable. I knew something had to change. That's when I decided to finally delve into Ayurveda, something my Dadi (grandmother) had always sworn by. I booked a 10-day retreat at the Nagarjuna Ayurvedic Centre in Kalady, Kerala – a place she highly recommended.

unnormalised: Landing in Kochi on 10/02/2023, I was immediately enveloped by a sense of calm. The air was thick with the scent of spices and damp earth, a stark contrast to the city. The centre itself was nestled amongst lush greenery, a haven away from the concrete jungle.
normalised: Landing in Kochi on tenth february two thousand and twenty three, I was immediately enveloped by a sense of calm. The air was thick with the scent of spices and damp earth, a stark contrast to the city. The centre itself was nestled amongst lush greenery, a haven away from the concrete jungle.

unnormalised: My days started early, around 06:00 hrs, with gentle yoga and pranayama. After breakfast, came the consultations with Dr. Lakshmi, who patiently listened to my woes and meticulously assessed my Prakriti (constitution). She determined my dominant Dosha was Pitta, explaining how the heat and stress of city life were exacerbating it.

unnormalised: The treatments were tailored specifically for me. From Abhyanga (oil massage) with medicated sesame oil to Shirodhara (pouring warm oil on the forehead), each session was deeply relaxing and restorative. There was even a fascinating treatment called Pizhichil, where warm oil is squeezed all over the body. I also diligently followed the prescribed diet, which was surprisingly delicious and focused on cooling, grounding foods. Think lots of rice, vegetables cooked with ghee, and cooling spices like coriander and fennel.

unnormalised: One evening, around 19:00 hrs, Dr. Lakshmi explained the importance of seasonal rhythms in Ayurveda. She emphasized how eating and living in harmony with the seasons can significantly improve overall health. I learned about the ancient texts like Charaka Samhita, which are still relevant even today. I even took a short cooking class on 15/02/2023 and learned to make a cooling cucumber raita.

unnormalised: By the end of my retreat, I felt like a new person. My skin was clearer, my digestion improved, and I felt a sense of calm I hadn't experienced in years. Ayurveda isn't just a treatment; it's a lifestyle. And my journey to incorporating its principles into my everyday life in Mumbai has just begun. I’m already planning my next trip back!
